Award.AwardTitle: Regulation of glutamate receptors at synapses by WD40 repeat proteins and the deubiquitinating enzyme USP-46 in C. elegans
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will increase our fundamental understanding of how neurons communicate with each other at the molecular level. Neuronal communication is essential for normal brain function and for learning and memory. Neurons communicate with each other at specialized junctions called synapses. Neurons release chemical signals, such as the neurotransmitter glutamate, which are received by downstream neurons via specialized protein detectors called glutamate receptors (GluRs). Changing the number or levels of GluRs at the synapse allows neurons to alter their communication, which enables the brain to learn, adapt and store memories. The specific focus of this project is to study how a new family of proteins control the number of GluRs at the synapse by preventing their degradation via the ubiquitin system. Ubiquitin is a tag that can be attached and removed from other proteins in a highly controlled manner. Proteins marked with ubiquitin are targeted to the cellular trash for degradation. This proposal studies how three proteins function together to specifically remove ubiquitin from GluRs, thus rescuing them from degradation and increasing receptor levels at the synapse. In addition, this project develops and launches an innovative, discovery-based Molecular Genetics and Cell Biology Lab Course for undergraduates, trains graduate students and postdoctoral fellows, and provides research opportunities for high school teachers and minority undergraduates.

Ubiquitin is an important regulator of synapse development and function. There are about 100 deubiquitinating enzymes (DUBs) that remove ubiquitin from other proteins, however very little is known about the DUBs that function at the synapse. The awardee's lab recently identified USP-46 as the first DUB to regulate GluRs. This proposal investigates how two proteins, WDR-20 and WDR-48, interact and regulate the activity of USP-46 to control GluRs levels at the synapse, and tests how these molecular changes affect behavior. This study uses genetic, biochemical, quantitative imaging and behavioral methods to study GluRs in the well-established genetic model organism C. elegans. Advantages of C. elegans include powerful genetic tools, a simple and defined nervous system, and simple behavioral assays to correlate neuronal function with whole animal behavior. The basic mechanisms involved in synapse development and function are conserved from nematodes to humans. Understanding how molecular changes at the synapse impact neuronal communication and behavior will provide fundamental information that could be applied to improve learning and memory, and to begin to uncover the molecular basis of learning and behavioral disorders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term goal of this research project is to understand how the neurons in the brain communicate with each other via special junctions called synapses. Molecular changes at synapses enables neurons to alter the communication of information, which is important for learning and memory. Glutamate is a major signaling molecule or neurotransmitter that neurons use to communicate. Glutamate is released from one side of the synapse (from the presynaptic neuron) and is detected by glutamate receptors on the other side of the synapse (in the postsynaptic neuron). There are many molecular pathways to control how much glutamate (the signal) is released from the presynaptic neuron and how many glutamate receptors (the detectors) are at the surface of the neuron on the postsynaptic side. The specific focus (Intellectual Merit) of this research project is to investigate a new molecular pathway that controls the amount of glutamate receptors on the postsynaptic side. This pathway consists of several genes called WDR-48, WDR-20 and USP-46. USP-46 is a specialized protein called a deubiquitinating enzyme that regulates the degradation of glutamate receptors. The WDR proteins can interact with USP-46 and control its activity. There are about 100 deubiquitinating enzymes in the human body, but very little is known about their function in the body or how they are regulated, especially at synapses in the nervous system. During this research, we discovered several interesting molecular pathways that regulate glutamate receptors and new important details of how USP-46 is controlled in neurons. For example, we discovered that the WDR proteins can regulate the amount of USP-46 in neurons by controlling its rates of degradation. We also discovered that changes in neuronal activity can control the levels of WDR-20 in neurons, which in turn can control USP-46 and the amount of glutamate receptors on the postsynaptic side. Finally, we showed that the ability of this WDR/USP-46 pathway to control glutamate receptors at the synapse is important for regulating behaviors mediated by glutamate signaling. This research project has also had significant impacts on the education and training of the next generation of research scientists (Broader Impacts). We developed and launched a 6 week-long genetics and neurobiology undergraduate research lab at Pine Manor College, which is a minority-serving institution, and a shorter genetics lab at a local high school. Graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, faculty from primarily undergraduate institutions, undergraduate and high school students have received research training from this project. The research discoveries we made during this project advances our basic understanding of how synapses communicate with each other, which is critical for understanding how the brain controls behavior and functions during learning and memory.
